awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: A Privacy-Preserving Meta-Data Analysis Framework for Cyber Abuse Research - Foundations, Tools and Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops and deploys a mobile communications metadata analysis platform, designed to predict incidents of youth harassment or abuse, drawing on participatory methods to drive research design decisions and maintain youth privacy. By analyzing communication patterns - rather than content - in collaboration with youth participants, this project makes innovative contributions by facilitating a contextualized understanding of youth abuse and harassment. In turn, this analysis supports the development of new, privacy-enhancing tools which allow for early intervention in instances of abuse and distress. Starting from the hypothesis that abused or distressed youth display observably different patterns of communication, the data collected allow researchers to visualize and analyze the everyday communication networks of youth in new ways, providing new opportunities to understand the structures and conditions of youth sociality and forms of abuse while simultaneously developing new predictive models and techniques.

In particular, this project 1) designs new methods grounded in participatory design that allows for a better understanding of the ways in which youth conceptualize privacy, adult supervision and surveillance online; 2) develops a highly scalable and practically deployable mobile platform for performing large scale metadata and survey analysis, taking the privacy needs of end users as a core design principle as identified from the first outcome; 3) ensures that the platform guarantees full anonymity to participants, while also allowing for longitudinal and flexible survey administration, metadata collection, and seamless scaling; 4) extracts novel features in the spatial and temporal domain from communication metadata logs (from texts and calls) that associate with cyber harassment and abuse; 5) leverages the features extracted to design context aware machine learning algorithms to quickly detect abnormal patterns from metadata logs. The project trains a number of graduate and undergraduate student in inter-disciplinary research. Long term impact of this project scale well beyond youth populations, and the project more generally moves towards the development of a fully anonymous, confidential, needs-based social scientific research platform.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is the design, deployent and validation of the feasibility of meta-data to detect intent of cyber-abuse. Specifically, the project attempted the development and deployment of a communications metadata analysis platform designed to predict and (eventually) intervene in incidents of youth harassment or abuse, drawing on youth concepts and experiences to drive design decisions and maintain youth privacy. Compared to existing works attempting a similar goal of detecting cyber-abuse using texts and images, this project focuses on using meta-data to do so. Meta-data is something that is collected during cyber-communications routinely by various entities, but is not widely used, since the data consists of those entities that are involved in processing the information, rather than the information itself. As such, meta-data is highly privacy preserving too. The premise of this project is founded upon the notion that even such types of meta-data can reveal clues about abusive cyber communications, even when the actual content of communication is not collected/processed. In this project, the major outcomes include a) a smart-phone app that can enable the collection of SMS messages from Android phones; b) a web-based platform to let subjects participate in a privacy preserving manner to annotate their own cyber communications as being abusive or not, while simultaneously sharing meta-data; c) trends collected that indicate discernible patterns. In parallel, we also demonstrated the power of another source of privacy-preserving meta data, namely NetFlow logs collected from Internet usage for applications related to profiling, authenticating and forecasting Internet traffic. Algorithms designed also have applications in predictive modeling of human behavior in cyber-space. The intellectual merit of the proposed project is the design of a user-friendly smart-phone app in Android that can enable a user see their past messages, and choose those conversations that created a level of discomfort in them. Subsequently, the app exports meta-data (i.e., time of message, length of message, whether the message was responded to or not, whether it contained any attachments) to a server, along with user given inputs. All of this is controlled by the user. Subsequently we designed algorithms to process such data to detect instances of discomforting messages. A Qualtrics based platform was also designed for easy recruitment. In parallel, the project also designed machine learning algorithms for related behavioral outcomes like user profiling, forecasting traffic and authentication of users all using privacy preserving NetFlow communication logs. The broader impacts of the project are a novel platform for the community to engage in cyber-abuse research while still preserving privacy, and algorithms that could potentially be used by government, military and industry also for a host of anomaly detection and authentication problems in cyber-space using behavioral insights and privacy preserving data.

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2021
Modified by: Sriram Chellappan
